title.narrative: Innovation and Sustainable Technology transfer on Pig Artificial Insemination and Capacity Building

description.narrative:
Pig production in Nigeria has really grown very well in Nigeria since our importation of exotic breeds for semen production and selling it to farmers to upgrade their existing breed and local breeds.
Many of our farmers that bought pigs from our institutions do not have knowledge of managing these exotic and hybrid pigs.
In summary the following problems were encountered:
• Inability to use AI for our indigenous breed, we were unable to break through in this area because of the anxiety or nervousness of this breed. Therefore there is need for training for our staff in this area.
• Capacity building for pig farmers, especially women and youth. In Nigeria, the challenge of animal protein inadequacy has led to series of livestock development drive by the government. However two major identified areas of focus are increasing the production of animals that are fast growing and reducing the production cost to make the meat and other animal products available and affordable to people. Thereby capacity building on pig production for women and youth will empower them.
• There is need to change the gene pool of our pigs to prevent inbreeding in southwestern Nigeria

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 09-06-2021: At this moment we did 1 online training for a university, it is too short now to have results in change of written class materials, this is coming in the next year.

title.narrative: B.I.5. % of scholarships awarded to minorities

comment.narrative: 22-03-2021: 4 of our participants are from a small tribe and they work in a remote area amongst farmers

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 22-03-2021: From the evaluation we learned that people gained new knowledge. Not everybody will use all new knowledge but the transfer of the knowledge to farmers/students should take place next year, See results evaluation sheet

title.narrative: B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative: 22-03-2021: Initially we selected 11 women and 9 men, 1 week 1 lady was replaced by 1 man from 1 of the participating universities

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: We aproached universities to promote our training programme on breeding and AI. In our communication we stated that preference would be given to female participants. During our training programme we did include gender as a subject. In this subject we made clear that the role of the female trainer is at least equal to the male but that because many small scal holders are female the impact from a female trainer/extensionist is higher as from a male trainer. All facilities used had equal opportunities for ladies as they had for man, in the training hall more toilets for ladies present as for men. In the contact after the training equal attention is paid to the participants. With 1 male and 2 female participants we do have a more detailed contact on improvements they want to make.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)
B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
Participants experienced the online training for the first time. They also see the opportunities to introduce this in their classes too with a cooperation programme between Nigerian and NL institutes.
More understanding of the techinical processess in breeding and AI for pigs and how they can de used in Nigeria but also the challenges they have in the execution of breeding and AI

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: Special attention in 2 training sessions about the role of the women, how to enhance this role and the importance of the women as pig husbandry producers.
